content:
Yeah, I just tried myself, Bill, and it's definitely not the best user experience to try to create an email address for a 3rd party provider from within Thunderbird.

Your best bet is to go to a provider (like Mailfence.com), create your email address there, then come back to Thunderbird and enter the credentials. Once you enter your credentials the first time in Thunderbird, it should auto-configure everything from there.
creator: Thundamike

content:
Ready to do some cool advanced-settings stuff? Let's try this solution:

Go to Thunderbird in the top menu and go to Settings --> General --> Scroll to the very bottom --> Click on Config Editor.

Once your in the config editor, ignore that silly-little caution sign and click on the "Show all" button. Once you do, a list should show, also a search bar. In the search bar, start to type in "layers.acceleration.disabled" until you find the match. Press the little left/right arrow icon next to this property to toggle it to "TRUE".

Then, Restart Thunderbird and see if you issue is corrected. If this does not correct your issue, then repeat the above steps to toggle the property back to its original setting, false.

Good Luck.
creator: Thundamike

content:
Sorry to hear that you are having this issue with The Messaging Co. What email address type were you trying to access? (e.g. @tpg.com.au, @iinet.net.au, etc.)?

This information might help us to confirm if your email account has migrated to the Messaging Co. IF you already feel confident that your account migrated over to TMC, then skip to the next step.

If we confirm your account did migrate over, then you will have to authenticate and regain access to your email via themessaging.co website. Once that is done, we can update the account settings in Thunderbird to match your new email provider's settings.

https://support.themessaging.co/hc/en-au/articles/8524389433615-I-need-support-Contact-the-the-support-team?utm_source=chatgpt.com
creator: Thundamike

content: You can add as many email accounts as you want in Mozilla Thunderbird, thereâ€™s no set limit per se. Thunderbird is an email client for viewing and organizing your emails, so you can use it to manage multiple accounts from different providers, like Gmail, Outlook, Mailfence, Yahoo, (or any provider) all in one place. Each account stays separate with its own inbox.
creator: Thundamike
